{"abstract": "The long-awaited listing of shares in Time Warner Cable \u2014 the United States\u2019 No. 2 cable provider after Comcast \u2014 could be delayed until March because of the legal wrangling in Adelphia Communications\u2018 bankruptcy case. That is one of the possibilities considered by Bear Stearns analyst Spencer Wang, who wrote in a research note Tuesday that, if the internecine battles among Adelphia\u2019s creditors continue, Time Warner could decide to try a traditional initial public offering as opposed to floating the stock through a court-approved reorganization plan. {"abstract": "Comcast, the nation\u2019s largest cable operator, said Tuesday that it was buying a small New Jersey cable operator for $483 million. Analysts said the price was high in light of the number of subscribers but understandable given the customers\u2019 affluence. {"abstract": "Comcast will test new devices that will keep track of its users and assemble a blacklist of heavy users. Those on the blacklist will find that all of their online activities may slow down at peak times: from downloading movies to checking e-mail. The company said it would not disclose what sort of usage it takes to get on the black list, how long someone stays on it and if there is any way to get off. Most significantly, Comcast won\u2019t even tell users if they are on the black list.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/06/04/comcast-tests-a-new-bandwidth-black-list/", "snippet": "Comcast will test new devices that will keep track of its users and assemble a blacklist of heavy users. {"abstract": "When last we left the new Big Ten Network \u2014 in a column I wrote last October \u2014 the new all-Big-Ten-sports-all-the-time network was in a long struggle to gain carriage with the big cable companies, starting with Comcast, Time Warner and Charter Communications. The cable guys were outraged because the Big Ten wanted a dollar per subscriber per month \u2014 nearly triple the price commanded by, say, CNN or the USA Network \u2014 and was further demanding a primo spot on extended basic, which is where everybody who starts a network wants to be. For their part, the cable companies wanted to relegate the Big Ten Network to a sports tier, where the fans who watched the games would also be the ones who pay for them. For the record, while I do not believe in a la carte cable pricing, I do think that sports should be treated as an exception: sports channels are so expensive \u2014 ESPN alone is some $3 a month a subscriber \u2014 that it is the single biggest reason your cable bill is so high. Putting sports channels on a sports tier makes sense, it seems to me.", "web_url": "https://executivesuite.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/08/27/the-big-ten-winssort-of/", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": "When last we left the new Big Ten Network \u2014 in a column I wrote last October \u2014 the new all-Big-Ten-sports-all-the-time network was in a long struggle to gain carriage with the big cable companies, starting with Comcast, Time Warner and Charter Communications. The cable guys were outraged because the Big Ten wanted a dollar per subscriber per month \u2014 nearly triple the price commanded by, say, CNN or the USA Network \u2014 and was further demanding a primo spot on extended basic, which is where everybody who starts a network wants to be. For their part, the cable companies wanted to relegate the Big Ten Network to a sports tier, where the fans who watched the games would also be the ones who pay for them. For the record, while I do not believe in a la carte cable pricing, I do think that sports should be treated as an exception: sports channels are so expensive \u2014 ESPN alone is some $3 a month a subscriber \u2014 that it is the single biggest reason your cable bill is so high. Putting sports channels on a sports tier makes sense, it seems to me.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Big Ten Wins\u2026Sort Of", "kicker": "Executive Suite", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2008-08-27T22:35:45+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Joe Nocera", "person": [{"firstname": "Joe", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Nocera", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/c8dfba91-27ed-5c16-939f-782fe4f34ccf", "word_count": 547, "uri": "nyt://article/c8dfba91-27ed-5c16-939f-782fe4f34ccf"}

{"abstract": "NBCUniversal held events in Midtown Manhattan on Monday night and Tuesday morning to shine a spotlight on efforts aimed at viewers who are women or speak Spanish.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/05/nbcuniversal-gears-up-for-upfront/", "snippet": "NBCUniversal held events in Midtown Manhattan on Monday night and Tuesday morning to shine a spotlight on efforts aimed at viewers who are women or speak Spanish.", "lead_paragraph": "Night and day, to borrow the words of Cole Porter, the NBCUniversal division of Comcast is wooing marketers and agencies as its broadcast networks, cable channels and online properties get ready for the 2011-12 \u201cupfront\u201d advertising sales season.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "NBCUniversal Gears Up for Upfront", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Television", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "National Broadcasting Co", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-04-05T20:18:38+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Stuart Elliott", "person": [{"firstname": "Stuart", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Elliott", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/c3d5bde3-e9d6-5ca4-a24d-193e9dd7405b", "word_count": 683, "uri": "nyt://article/c3d5bde3-e9d6-5ca4-a24d-193e9dd7405b"}

{"abstract": "The films will be made available to Comcast customers and others, beginning Monday.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/10/holocaust-memories-via-cable/", "snippet": "The films will be made available to Comcast customers and others, beginning Monday.", "lead_paragraph": "Comcast, the nation\u2019s top cable company, is distributing 10 films about the Holocaust in a public service project it is calling \u201cDays of Remembrance.\u201d And it started with an unrelated telephone call to the directorSteven Spielberg.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Holocaust Memories, via Cable", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Cable Television", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Holocaust and the Nazi Era", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Movies", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Spielberg, Steven", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Comcast Corp", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-04-10T23:28:09+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Brian Stelter", "person": [{"firstname": "Brian", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stelter", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/107cf316-1c6a-52cd-955f-2faf7390d6c3", "word_count": 336, "uri": "nyt://article/107cf316-1c6a-52cd-955f-2faf7390d6c3"}

{"abstract": "Comcast, the nation\u2019s largest cable operator, will now offer a selection of TV shows from all four of the major networks.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/27/comcast-bolsters-its-on-demand-roster/", "snippet": "Comcast, the nation\u2019s largest cable operator, will now offer a selection of TV shows from all four of the major networks.", "lead_paragraph": "Comcast said Wednesday that it had become the first cable or satellite provider to have TV shows from each of the four major networks on its video-on-demand service.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Comcast Bolsters Its On-Demand Roster", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Television", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Comcast Corp", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-04-27T16:35:45+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Brian Stelter", "person": [{"firstname": "Brian", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stelter", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/f8cd072a-7c38-53e4-9778-020c2452487e", "word_count": 378, "uri": "nyt://article/f8cd072a-7c38-53e4-9778-020c2452487e"}

{"abstract": "The CBS Corporation said its improved results came from strong advertising sales, and Comcast said its cable holdings bolstered its bottom line.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/04/business/media/04cbs.html", "snippet": "The CBS Corporation said its improved results came from strong advertising sales, and Comcast said its cable holdings bolstered its bottom line.", "lead_paragraph": "Both Comcast and the CBS Corporation reported strongly positive first-quarter earnings Tuesday, in one case reflecting largely the strength of its cable television holdings, in the other its strength in advertising sales for its broadcasting operations.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Net Incomes Rise Solidly for CBS and Comcast", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Net Incomes Rise Solidly For CBS And Comcast", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Comcast Corp", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "ADVERTISING AND MARKETING", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "CBS Corp", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Television", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Cable Television", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-05-04T01:26:09+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Bill Carter", "person": [{"firstname": "Bill", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Carter", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/80fac480-07c9-5920-b1db-2e58435a49cb", "word_count": 592, "uri": "nyt://article/80fac480-07c9-5920-b1db-2e58435a49cb"}

{"abstract": "In Time Warner Cable\u2019s biggest acquisition since 2006, it has reached a deal for Insight Communications, a person with knowledge of the deal said.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/15/business/media/time-warner-is-said-to-acquire-midwest-cable-operator.html", "snippet": "In Time Warner Cable\u2019s biggest acquisition since 2006, it has reached a deal for Insight Communications, a person with knowledge of the deal said.", "lead_paragraph": "Time Warner Cable, the second biggest cable television company in the United States after Comcast, is near a deal to acquire Insight Communications, a large operator in the Midwest, for about $3 billion, a person with knowledge of the deal said on Sunday night.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Time Warner Cable Is Said to Acquire Midwest Cable Operator", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Time Warner Is Expected To Announce Cable Merger", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Cable Television", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Insight Communications Inc", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Time Warner Cable Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-08-15T00:18:11+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Brian Stelter", "person": [{"firstname": "Brian", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stelter", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a931cf46-0e43-5b95-b3fb-e7124a17a66c", "word_count": 350, "uri": "nyt://article/a931cf46-0e43-5b95-b3fb-e7124a17a66c"}

{"abstract": "General Electric will team up with Cinelan to make 30 three-minute films by well-known directors, including Morgan Spurlock.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/g-e-to-produce-short-films-about-innovation/", "snippet": "General Electric will team up with Cinelan to make 30 three-minute films by well-known directors, including Morgan Spurlock.", "lead_paragraph": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 General Electric just can\u2019t stay away from the movies. Barely eight months after ceding control of NBC Universal and its Universal Studios to Comcast, G.E. is diving into the documentary world as the financial backer of 30 three-minute films by directors including Morgan Spurlock (\u201cPOM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold\u201d), Joe Berlinger (\u201cCrude\u201d), Barbara Kopple (\u201cShut Up and Sing\u201d) and Alex Gibney (\u201cMagic Trip: Ken Kesey\u2019s Search for a Kool Place\u201d).", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "G.E. to Produce Short Films About Innovation", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Documentary Films and Programs", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Movies", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Spurlock, Morgan", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "General Electric Company", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-08-28T20:54:01+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Michael Cieply", "person": [{"firstname": "Michael", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cieply", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/1c296ca9-fe48-59cd-9158-eb8588caf61c", "word_count": 363, "uri": "nyt://article/1c296ca9-fe48-59cd-9158-eb8588caf61c"}

The virus normally doesn\u2019t travel from person to person, but scientists managed to make a highly transmissible form (at least in ferrets, which provide a good model of what viruses will do in people). {"abstract": "Having the top show on television presents a rare opportunity for any network, but especially NBC, which has been so far behind for so long.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/03/business/nbc-finds-a-winner-in-the-voice.html", "snippet": "Having the top show on television presents a rare opportunity for any network, but especially NBC, which has been so far behind for so long.", "lead_paragraph": "\u00a0The cellphone of NBCUniversal\u2019s chief executive, Stephen B. Burke, rang early on the morning of April 28 last year. Alan Wurtzel, the company\u2019s president of research, was so excited that he had trouble speaking. \u201cWe got a 5.1,\u201d he finally said. Mr. Burke was at the gym, and given the background noise, he figured he wasn\u2019t hearing correctly. \u201cI said, We got a 5.1 in the key demographic,\u201d Mr. Wurtzel repeated, which meant that Nielsen estimated that 11.8 million viewers in the all-important 18-to-49 demographic had tuned in \u2014 a breakout number for a new show.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "1", "source": "The {"abstract": "To reach the multitude of online services competing for your attention, you must first get through a bottleneck that is not competitive at all: high-speed broadband access.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/09/business/economy/net-neutrality-and-economic-equality-are-intertwined.html", "snippet": "To reach the multitude of online services competing for your attention, you must first get through a bottleneck that is not competitive at all: high-speed broadband access.", "lead_paragraph": "Imagine a network of private highways that reserved a special lane for Fords to zip through, unencumbered by all the other brands of cars trundling along the clogged, shared lanes. Think of the prices Ford could charge. {"abstract": "One of Mr. Leno\u2019s jokes: \u201cAs you may have heard, our parent company has downsized \u2018The Tonight Show.\u2019 And we\u2019ve consistently been No. 1 in the ratings. And if you know anything about our network, that kind of thing is frowned upon.\u201d", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/21/jay-leno-snipes-at-comcast-over-tonight-show-cutbacks/", "snippet": "One of Mr. Leno\u2019s jokes: \u201cAs you may have heard, our parent company has downsized \u2018The Tonight Show.\u2019 And we\u2019ve consistently been No. 1 in the ratings. And if you know anything about our network, that kind of thing is frowned upon.\u201d", "lead_paragraph": "On Friday, the NBC network, part of Comcast, imposed budget cuts at \u201cThe Tonight Show,\u201d which included layoffs of between 20 and 25 staff members. The host, Jay Leno, took a pay cut, according to a person with direct knowledge of the cuts, in order to limit the number of layoffs. On Monday, Mr. Leno joined the long line of late-night hosts who use the monologue to take aim at the boss: \u201cAs you may have heard, our parent company has downsized \u2018The Tonight Show.\u2019 And we\u2019ve consistently been No. 1 in the ratings. {"abstract": "Online advertising shifts to follow consumers online, the BBC\u2019s legal woes mount, and how both sides in the conflict over Gaza are using social networks.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/16/the-breakfast-meeting-targeted-ads-reshape-online-media-and-gaza-conflict-on-the-internet/", "snippet": "Online advertising shifts to follow consumers online, the BBC\u2019s legal woes mount, and how both sides in the conflict over Gaza are using social networks.", "lead_paragraph": "Online advertising is shifting toward \u201cprogrammatic buying,\u201d a system that allows advertisers to follow individual consumers online, Tanzina Vega writes. It is a different method for reaching an online audience, one that gives less value to the context (that is, the writing, photos and video surrounding the ad) than to the individual who happens to visiting that particular site. Advertisers like Nike, Comcast, Progressive and Procter & Gamble are using programmatic buying and it is punishing traditional online publishers who are receiving a smaller share of ad dollars as marketers can buy across a broader range of sites.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Targeted Ads Reshape Online Media, and Gaza Conflict on the Internet", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Online Advertising", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Netanyahu, Benjamin", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Thompson, Mark John (1957- )", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "British Broadcasting Corp", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Gaza Strip", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-11-16T14:41:44+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Noam Cohen", "person": [{"firstname": "Noam", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cohen", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/24cb5e2c-b9f2-5330-9fa1-c68a087f5706", "word_count": 518, "uri": "nyt://article/24cb5e2c-b9f2-5330-9fa1-c68a087f5706"}

{"abstract": "Two Harvard graduates are trying to reconcile students\u2019 viewing habits with the desire of cable companies and programmers to be paid for wireless content; NBC is looking for newsmen and newswomen to star in a planned reality show; and WBEZ, the Chicago public radio station, is hoping that Chicagoans will help create a new generation of listeners.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/28/the-breakfast-meeting-courting-future-cable-subscribers-a-newspaper-reality-show-and-a-saucy-ad-campaign/", "snippet": "Two Harvard graduates are trying to reconcile students\u2019 viewing habits with the desire of cable companies and programmers to be paid for wireless content; NBC is looking for newsmen and newswomen to star in a planned reality show; and WBEZ, the Ch...", "lead_paragraph": "Tivli, a start-up founded by two Harvard graduates, is trying to reconcile students\u2019 viewing habits, which increasingly involve mobile devices, with the desire of cable companies like Comcast and programmers like HBO to be paid for wireless content. As Brian Stelter reports, resident students at Harvard and, of as of last week, Yale, can use a service created by Tivli to stream local TV stations, a couple of dozen cable channels and the universities\u2019 own in-house channels to computers, tablets or video game consoles. This ability, available anywhere on campus, may be part of the answer to a conundrum for the television industry. Young people watch less TV than they used to, and some say they do not see the point of an expensive cable or satellite subscription. If they become accustomed to viewing programming through services like HBO GO while in college, however, some believe it could lead them to become cable subscribers after they graduate.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Courting Future Cable Subscribers, a Newspaper Reality Show, and a Saucy Ad Campaign", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Newspapers", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Radio", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Reality Television", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Comcast Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Harvard University", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Home Box Office", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "National Broadcasting Co", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "ALASKA", "rank": 8, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Chicago (Ill)", "rank": 9, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Montana", "rank": 10, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-01-28T13:00:57+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By The Editors", "person": [], "organization": "The Editors"}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/710f5f6f-1195-58fd-9311-7c56f659498b", "word_count": 481, "uri": "nyt://article/710f5f6f-1195-58fd-9311-7c56f659498b"}

Web sites that help uncover new books, like Goodreads.com, have become indispensable for readers, writers and publishers; and Slacker, a digital music service, takes aim at Pandora in new advertisements.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/13/the-breakfast-meeting-comcast-buys-rest-of-nbcuniversal-and-sites-that-appeal-to-book-lovers/", "snippet": "Comcast bought the rest of NBCUniversal from General Electric for $16.7 billion; Web sites that help uncover new books, like Goodreads.com, have become indispensable for readers, writers and publishers; and Slacker, a digital music service, takes ...", "lead_paragraph": "9:28 a.m. | Updated Comcast agreed to pay General Electric $16.7 billion to acquire their remaining 49 percent stake in NBCUniversal on Tuesday, Amy Chozick and Brian Stelter write. Brian Roberts, Comcast\u2019s chief executive, said that the acquisition was a necessary step given the rapidly changing television business and the necessity of owning content. Comcast bought a 51 percent share in NBCUniversal in early 2011, with the option of buying the rest of the company over the next seven years; the process was accelerated at least in part by a clash in corporate cultures between G.E. and Comcast. The deal will also include 30 Rockefeller Plaza and the CNBC headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., for about $1.4 billion. Naming rights are included in the deal, so the red G.E. sign atop 30 Rockefeller Plaza could be replaced with a Comcast logo.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Comcast Buys Rest of NBCUniversal, and Sites That Appeal to Book Lovers", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2013-02-13T14:11:39+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Daniel E. {"abstract": "Reports include quarterly earnings from Facebook, Comcast and General Motors, as well as vehicle sales and unemployment numbers for April.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/29/business/economic-reports-for-the-week-of-april-29.html", "snippet": "Reports include quarterly earnings from Facebook, Comcast and General Motors, as well as vehicle sales and unemployment numbers for April.", "lead_paragraph": "ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include personal income and spending, pending home sales and the Dallas Fed\u2019s manufacturing activity (Monday); the Standard & Poor\u2019s/Case-Shiller Home Price Index, the Chicago Purchasing Managers\u2019 Index and consumer confidence for April (Tuesday); A.D.P. employment for April, the I.S.M. manufacturing index for April and United States vehicle sales for April (Wednesday); the trade deficit for March and weekly initial jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for April (Friday). {"abstract": "Reed Hastings said that once Netflix agreed to pay Comcast for a better connection, Netflix customers no longer experienced delays streaming video.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/21/business/media/netflix-chief-alters-view-on-net-deal.html", "snippet": "Reed Hastings said that once Netflix agreed to pay Comcast for a better connection, Netflix customers no longer experienced delays streaming video.", "lead_paragraph": "Less than a month after Netflix insisted that its deal to pay Comcast to get a more direct connection to the company\u2019s Internet pipes had nothing to do with net neutrality, Netflix\u2019s chief executive, Reed Hastings, said Thursday that, well, yes it did.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Netflix Chief Alters View on Net Neutrality", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Netflix Chief Alters View on Net Deal", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "persons", "value": "Wyatt, Edward", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Net Neutrality", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Netflix Inc", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Comcast Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Hastings, Reed", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-03-21T00:25:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Edward Wyatt", "person": [{"firstname": "Edward", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Wyatt", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f709cdee-5f79-5887-be31-2fff9335c1a8", "word_count": 392, "uri": "nyt://article/f709cdee-5f79-5887-be31-2fff9335c1a8"}

[{"abstract": "A Fed rule could mean banks need to find an additional $68 billion to limit risk. | The firm chosen to oversee the revamped SAC has links to the fund. | Investors may be souring on I.P.O.\u2019s. | Comcast makes its case for a merger with Time Warner Cable.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/04/09/morning-agenda-an-order-for-banks-to-hold-more-capital/", "snippet": "A Fed rule could mean banks need to find an additional $68 billion to limit risk. | The firm chosen to oversee the revamped SAC has links to the fund. | Investors may be souring on I.P.O.\u2019s. | Comcast makes its case for a merger with Time Warner C...", "lead_paragraph": "\u201cFederal regulators on Tuesday approved a simple rule that could do more to rein in Wall Street than most other parts of a sweeping overhaul that has descended on the biggest banks since the financial crisis,\u201d Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The rule increases to 5 percent, from roughly 3 percent, a threshold called the leverage ratio, which measures the amount of capital that a bank holds against its assets. The rule is scheduled to take effect at the start of 2018.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "An Order for Banks to Hold More Capital", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-04-09T11:57:07+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/cbbf6380-b53e-5cbf-9ef4-0f609660b538", "word_count": 2257, "uri": "nyt://article/cbbf6380-b53e-5cbf-9ef4-0f609660b538"}, {"abstract": "The judiciary panel expressed concern over higher costs for consumers if a merger with Time Warner Cable were approved, but a Comcast executive downplayed the likelihood.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/10/business/media/senate-committee-begins-its-review-of-comcast-deal.html", "snippet": "The judiciary panel expressed concern over higher costs for consumers if a merger with Time Warner Cable were approved, but a Comcast executive downplayed the likelihood.", "lead_paragraph": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee expressed concern on Wednesday that the proposed $45 billion merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable would raise the prices consumers pay for cable television and high-speed Internet service while leaving them with fewer choices for video programming. {"abstract": "Comcast is locked into its deal with Time Warner Cable unless it gets a timely assist from the Federal Communications Commission, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/11/13/net-neutrality-review-could-give-comcast-an-out-in-the-time-warner-cable-deal/", "snippet": "Comcast is locked into its deal with Time Warner Cable unless it gets a timely assist from the Federal Communications Commission, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.", "lead_paragraph": "Comcast\u2019s acquisition of Time Warner Cable has already drawn many heated detractors to urge the Federal Communications Commission to reject the deal. Now, it has been hit been hit yet again by President Obama\u2019s endorsement of net neutrality. Comcast may have buyer\u2019s remorse, but it may find that ironically, the only way out is to have the F.C.C. block this deal. M.&A. makes strange bedfellows indeed. {"abstract": "Net neutrality could give Comcast a way out of its Time Warner Cable acquisition. | Warren E. Buffett\u2019s deal for Duracell satisfies a number of his deal-making preferences. | Virgin America to begin trading. | Goldman seeks to lure tech talent.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/11/14/morning-agenda-net-neutralitys-effect-on-comcast/", "snippet": "Net neutrality could give Comcast a way out of its Time Warner Cable acquisition. | Warren E. Buffett\u2019s deal for Duracell satisfies a number of his deal-making preferences. | Virgin America to begin trading. | Goldman seeks to lure tech talent.", "lead_paragraph": "NET NEUTRALITY COULD AFFECT COMCAST\u2019S DEAL | Comcast\u2019s $45 billion deal for Time Warner Cable may have seemed like a good idea earlier this year. But now that President Obama has endorsed net neutrality, Comcast might have buyer\u2019s remorse, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. Given how much detractors have urged the Federal Communications Commission to reject the deal, Comcast may now find, ironically, that the only way out is to have the F.C.C. block the transaction. \u201cThis F.C.C. battle all comes down to whether bigger in and of itself is a problem, and President Obama\u2019s statements only add to the troubles for this deal,\u201d Mr. Davidoff Solomon writes.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Net Neutrality\u2019s Effect on Comcast", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-11-14T12:32:10+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/e21da142-b56b-55d2-9b67-9634e6dc1679", "word_count": 2282, "uri": "nyt://article/e21da142-b56b-55d2-9b67-9634e6dc1679"}

{"abstract": "Charter wants to buy Time Warner Cable and Bright House. In an F.C.C. filing, it outlined why its ownership would be beneficial, all the while dissociating itself from Comcast\u2019s failed takeover.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/26/business/media/charter-says-its-mergers-would-do-online-video-no-harm.html", "snippet": "Charter wants to buy Time Warner Cable and Bright House. In an F.C.C. filing, it outlined why its ownership would be beneficial, all the while dissociating itself from Comcast\u2019s failed takeover.", "lead_paragraph": "Charter Communications, in an attempt to distinguish itself from Comcast and its failed takeover of Time Warner Cable, promised federal regulators on Thursday that a pair of deals totaling $67.1 billion would pose no threat to the growing market for online video because the combined company\u2019s future depended more on broadband than on its legacy video business.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Charter Makes Its Case for 2 Mergers, Telling F.C.C. {"abstract": "Billboards, long used by big brands to promote their products, and more recently by tech companies, are flourishing compared with other traditional media.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/05/business/media/look-up-in-the-digital-age-billboards-are-far-from-dead.html", "snippet": "Billboards, long used by big brands to promote their products, and more recently by tech companies, are flourishing compared with other traditional media.", "lead_paragraph": "When Axl Rose ended a 23-year feud with his former Guns N\u2019 Roses bandmates, Duff McKagan and Slash, and agreed to reunite with them onstage in 2016, the band unveiled its North American tour in an unusual way.
